case_name: Saradindu and another v. defendants (descendants of Durgadas Mukherjee)

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 2394 of 1966 filed by special leave from judgment and decree dated June 26, 1964 of Calcutta High Court in Appeal from Appellate Decree No. 1011 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 2394 of 1966. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated June 26, 1964 of the Calcutta High Court in Appeal from Appellate Decree No. 1011 of 1962.

facts.text: Parties are descendants of Durgadas Mukherjee who died many years back leaving six sons and property recorded as Dag No. 444 Khatian No. 72 in Mauja Barasat, District 24 Parganas during last Cadastral survey.

anchor.surface_text: The parties are all descendants of one Durgadas Mukherjee who died many years back, leaving six sons and inter alia the property which is the subject matter of this litigation, recorded as Dag No. 444 Khatian No. 72 in Mauja Barasat, District 24 Parganas during the last Cadastral survey.

facts.text: First plaintiff Saradindu is great grandson of Durgadas Mukherjee of the branch of the youngest son.

anchor.surface_text: Of the two plaintiffs the first Saradindu is a great grandson of the said Durgadas Mukherjee of the branch of the youngest son,

facts.text: Second plaintiff is grandson in another branch of Durgadas Mukherjee.

anchor.surface_text: his company plaintiff being a grandson in another branch.

facts.text: Defendants belong to other branches of the family of Durgadas Mukherjee.

anchor.surface_text: The defendants belong to other branches of the said family.

facts.text: First plaintiff based title on conveyances from other family members and purchase at execution sale of fractional interest of members of Bama Charan branch, second son of Durgadas.

anchor.surface_text: The first plaintiff based his title on several companyveyances from other members of the family as also purchase at an execution sale of a fractional interest of the members of the branch of Bama Charan, the second son of Durgadas.

facts.text: Second plaintiff claims title by inheritance.

anchor.surface_text: The second plaintiff claims by inheritance.

facts.text: Property consists of 34 acres with two separate structures: eastern Bamacharan Babus Bati and western Baitakhana Bati.

anchor.surface_text: The property companysists of 34 acres together with two structures thereon which are quite separate from each other. One portion of the structures i.e. that to the east, popularly known as Bamacharan Babus Bati is a fairly companymodious building with a separate municipal number. The other structure in the western portion known as Baitakhana Bati

facts.text: Baitakhana Bati is admittedly joint property of descendants of Durgadas.

anchor.surface_text: was and is admittedly the joint property of the descendants of Durgadas with a municipal number of its own.

facts.text: Plaintiffs claim land and two buildings are joint property.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs claim that the land and the two buildings are joint property

facts.text: Appellants claim exclusive title to eastern building Bamacharan Babus Bati and land on which it stands.

anchor.surface_text: while the whom are appellants before this the said eastern building with the case of the appellants was that the companytesting defendants, some of Court, claim exclusive title to land on which it stands.

facts.text: Eastern structure constructed by Bama Charan with his own money and sharers of Bama Charan gave up interest in land by ekramamas.

anchor.surface_text: The eastern structure was companystructed, by Bama Charan with his own money and that. the companysharers of Bama Charan, by ekramamas, gave up their interest in the land on which the same stood.

facts.text: High Court found no evidence that Bama Charan built eastern building with own money or was exclusive owner or sharers gave up ownership of subjacent soil, rejected exclusive title.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court agreeing with the finding of the first appellate companyrt found that there was number evidence on record to show that Bama Charan had put up the said building with his own money or that he was the exclusive owner of the said two storeyed building- or that the other companysharers gave up their ownership of the subjacent soil and rejected the exclusive title sought to be set up with regard thereto.

facts.text: High Court rejected plaintiffs' story of permissive possession of defendants over eastern building.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court also agreed with the lower appellate companyrt in rejecting the story of permissive possession of the defendants over the said building set up by the plaintiffs

facts.text: Heirs in line of Bama Charan including appellants were in separate possession of eastern two-storeyed building at all material times.

anchor.surface_text: and came to the companyclu 13-918 Sup. C.I./71 sion that at all material times the heirs in the line of Bama Charan including the appellants were in separate possession of the eastern two-storeyed building.

facts.text: First plaintiff became co-sharer with heirs of Bama Charan in 1941 by private treaties kobalas and auction purchase of shares of three sons in execution of award under Co-operative Societies Act.

anchor.surface_text: No question can be raised about the first plaintiffs having become a company sharer with the heirs in the line of Bama Charan.in the year 1941 by private treaties and the auction purchase of the shares of three of his sons in execution of an award under a Co-operative Societies Act.

facts.text: Kobalas Ex. 6 series conveyed fractional interest in shares of descendants of Bama Charan and Shyama Charan.

anchor.surface_text: By the kobalas the first plaintiff acquired fractional interest in the shares of some of the descendants of Bama Charan as also of the descend- ants of his brother Shyama Charan.

facts.text: Sale certificate Ex. 9a following auction purchase references Dalan 3 Privy 2.

anchor.surface_text: In the sale certificate following the auction purchase there is a reference to Dalan 3 Privy 2 but there is numberexpress reference to these in the koabalas  Ex. 6 series .

facts.text: Trial court and first appellate court held kobalas Ex.6 series and sale certificate Ex.9a included all structures on the plot, not excluding eastern building.

anchor.surface_text: In the companyrts below the defendants-appellants companytended that the eastern two- storeyed building was neither intended to be number was companyveyed under Ex.6 series kobalas and Ex. 9 a , the sale certificate. Both the trial companyrt and the first a ale companyrt held that the kobalas and sale certificate were sufficiently companyprehensive so as to include all or any structures which stood on the aforesaid plot of land at the material time and that there was, numberhing express or implied in the kobalas to show that the two-storeyed building on the eastern side was intended to be excluded from their operation.

facts.text: Suit for partition filed in 1955.

anchor.surface_text: inasmuch as the suit for partition was filed in 1955

facts.text: Eastern two-storeyed building occupied by military authorities under Defence of India Act and Rules 1939 for four years from 1942 to 1946.

anchor.surface_text: that the two-storeyed building in the eastern wing had indisputably been in the occupation of the military authorities by requisition under the Defence of India Act and the Rules, 1939 for four years from 1942 to 1946.

facts.text: Order of requisition dated May 28, 1942 under rule 75-A of Defence of India Rules by Collector of 24 Parganas for building from 8-2-1942.

anchor.surface_text: The order of requisition dated May 28, 1942 made under rule 75-A of the Defence of India Rules issued by the Collector of the District of 24 Parganas shows that the building together with fixtures, fittings etc. was to be placed at the disposal and under the companytrol of Brigadier Commander 36 Indian Infantry Brigade, Barrackpore on and from 8-2-1942 until six months after the termination of the war unless relinquished earlier.

facts.text: Copy of notice of requisition served on Prakash Chandra Mukherjee described as owner occupier.

anchor.surface_text: A companyy of the numberice was served on Prakash Chandra Mukherjee of Barasat described as the owner occupier of the said property.

facts.text: Notice of award under s.19 Defence of India Act 1939 to Prokash Chandra Mukherjee for compensation Rs.125.

anchor.surface_text: The numberice of an award under s. 19 of the Defence of India Act 1939 addressed to Prokash Chandra Mukherjee, another descendant of Bama Charan shows that companypensation had been adjudged and awarded in respect of the property at Rs. 125.

facts.text: Notice dated June 24, 1946 for restoration of possession of plot No.444 to Pankaj Kumar Mukherjee and others on July 2, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: A third numberice dated June 24, 1946 sent out from the office of the Land Acquisition Collector addressed to Pankaj Kumar Mukherjee and others shows that possession of Cadastral survey plot No. 444 Mouza Barasat requisitioned under rule 75-A would be restored to, the addressee on July 2, 1946.

facts.text: Ex. D memo forwarding cheque Rs.2100 as rent for terminal compensation to Prokash Chandra Mukherjee and others.

anchor.surface_text: Ex. D, a memo forwarding a cheque for Rs. 2,100 was addressed to Prokash Chandra Mukherjee. and others by way of rent for terminal companypensation in respect of the premises which had been requisitioned.

holdings.text: Defendants-appellants did not perfect title to the eastern building by adverse possession for 12 years under Art. 144 Limitation Act 1908.

anchor.surface_text: the main question in this appeal is, whether the defendants-appellants perfected their title to the property in respect of which partition was claimed by the plaintiffs by adverse, possession for the prescriptive-period of twelve years or more. The relevant facts are as follows.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Requisition under Defence of India Rules 1939 r.75A from 1942-1946 interrupted continuity of exclusive possession; period from 1946-1955 insufficient for 12 years.

holdings.text: Possession by government or military authorities under rule 75-A Defence of India Rules 1939 is not in the character of an agent or by implied permission of true owner or prior occupier.

anchor.surface_text: In our view possession by Government or the military autho- rities of immovable property under rule 75-A of the Defence of India Rules 1939 cannot be said to be in the character of an agent or by virtue of any implied permission from the true owner or occupier.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory scheme under ss.2,19,19B empowers independent requisition, taking possession irrespective of prior rights; delivery discharges government without attributing possession to prior party.

holdings.text: Heirs of Bama Charan did not acquire title by adverse possession to eastern portion (Bamacharan Babus Bati).

anchor.surface_text: The point for consideration before the High Court was and before us is, whether by such exclusive possession the heirs in the line of Bama Charan including the appellants acquired title by adverse possession to the eastern portion i.e. Bama charan Babus Bati.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Exclusive possession not continuous due to government requisition interrupting prescriptive period under Limitation Act.

holdings.text: Kobalas Ex.6 series and sale certificate Ex.9a conveyed fractional shares including the eastern two-storeyed building; nothing express or implied excluding it.

anchor.surface_text: In the courts below the defendants-appellants contended that the eastern two- storeyed building was neither intended to be nor was conveyed under Ex.6 series kobalas and Ex. 9 a , the sale certificate. Both the trial court and the first appellate court held that the kobalas and sale certificate were sufficiently comprehensive so as to include all or any structures

holdings.reasoning_summary: Documents comprehensive for plot Dag No.444 including all structures; lower courts' findings accepted by High Court and Supreme Court.

holdings.text: Plaintiffs' prayers for preliminary decree for partition and appointment of commissioner include embedded claim for possession via demarcation of shares.

anchor.surface_text: The last, point put forward was that the plaintiffs had not asked for possession in their plaint. This can be rejected summarily. The prayers in the plaint not only include one, for preliminary decree for partition but for the appointment of a commissioner for effecting partition of the property by separating the shares of the plaintiffs from those of the defendants in the suit property.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prayer for partition by separation of shares inherently includes possession through demarcation.

holdings.text: No evidence supports exclusive title claim that Bama Charan constructed eastern building with own funds or co-sharers relinquished subjacent soil rights via ekramamas.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court agreeing with the finding of the first appellate court found that there was no evidence on record to show that Bama Charan had put up the said building with his own money or that he was the exclusive owner of the said two storeyed building- or that the other co-sharers gave up their ownership of the subjacent soil and rejected the exclusive title sought to be set up with regard thereto.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Conclusion of fact by lower courts affirmed; no scrutiny required.

holdings.text: Heirs of Bama Charan were in separate possession of eastern building at all material times; plaintiffs' permissive possession story rejected.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court also agreed with the lower appellate court in rejecting the story of permissive possession of the defendants over the said building set up by the plaintiffs and came to the conclusion that at all material times the heirs in the line of Bama Charan including the appellants were in separate possession of the eastern two-storeyed building.

precedents.citation: Karan Singh v. Bakar Ali Khan 1

anchor.surface_text: Karan Singh v. Bakar Ali Khan 1 in coming to the conclusion that such requisition put an end to the claim for adverse possession, if any, which might have started from an anterior date. The Judicial Committee held that possession of the defendants since 1863 when the Collector had relinquished possession was number, 12 years possession but it was companytended on behalf of the defendant that he was justified in tacking to his possession the possession of the Collector from 1861. The Board found that pending a dispute between the parties the Collector, in order to secure the Government revenue had attached and taken possession of the property and retained possession of it from 1861 until October 1863 when in companysequence of the decree of the civil companyrt he delivered possession to the defendant and paid over to him the surplus profits of the estate after deducting the Government revenue and expenses. As the suit was brought in the year 1874 the period of 12 years had to companymence some time in 1862. The Board observed that it must be assumed that the Collector properly took possession for the purpose of protecting the Government revenue. It was the duty of the Collector whi1st in possession under the attachment, to companylect the rents from the ryots, and having paid the Government revenue and the expenses of companylection to pay over the surplus to the real owner. If the defendant was the real owner the surplus belonged  1  9 I.A. 99. to him but if, on the other hand, the infants were the right owners, then the surplus belonged to them. The Collector, by paying over the money to Karan Singh, did number give Karan Singh a title. Accordingly it was held that the suit was number barred by limitation.

precedents.case_name: Karan Singh v Bakar Ali Khan
precedents.cited_proposition: Government possession by Collector under attachment cannot be tacked onto defendant's possession to complete prescriptive period; suit not barred by limitation
precedents.cited_holding: the suit was number barred by limitation

precedents.citation: Bobett v. The South Eastern Railway Co. 1

anchor.surface_text: Bobett v. The South Eastern Railway Co. 1 . In our view neither the above passage number this judgment helps the appellants in any way. One of the points raised in Bobetts case was, whether the plaintiff in an action of trespass and to recover possession of land companyld be allowed to set up a plea that inasmuch as he had been let into possession by the defendants or that he had been in possession to the exclusion of the defendants without any tenancy at all during the time required by the Statute of Limitation for the acquisition of a prescriptive title, he was absolutely entitled to the land when ousted by the defendants. It was argued on behalf of the defendants that even if the plaintiff was a tenant at will for the requisite period and in exclusive possession of the land the Statute of Limitation did number apply to the case, for the land in question was inalienable by the companypany under s. 127 of the Lands Clauses Act and therefore companyld, by the mere aches of its officers have vested in the plaintiff companytrary to the intention of the Legislature which only allowed the companypany to take possession of the land for the purposes of the undertaking and subject to the provisions of its Acts and number give it up to others. There on a companysideration of s. 7 of 3 and 4 wm. 4, c. 27 and other statutory provisions Denman, J. arrived at the companyclusion that the mere fact that the property in question was land taken for the purposes of the undertaking and number superfluous land, would number prevent the plaintiff if he had exclusive possession since 1863, either as a  1  1882 9 Q.B. 424.

precedents.case_name: Bobett v The South Eastern Railway Co
precedents.cited_proposition: Exclusive possession for statutory period acquires title even if land taken under Lands Clauses Consolidation Act 1845 for public undertaking and not superfluous land
precedents.cited_holding: the mere fact that the property in question was land taken for the purposes of the undertaking and number superfluous land, would number prevent the plaintiff if he had exclusive possession since 1863... from being entitled to the land by virtue of the Statute of Limitations

anchor.surface_text: Dagdu v. Kalu 1 . In this case it was found that the plaintiff had been admittedly out of possession of the lands since 1881 and the defendant had been in adverse possession of them from that time until the date of suit October 2, 1895, with the exception of a period of three years during which period he had been dispossessed by one Barsu who wrongly alleged that he was a donee of the plaintiffs. On that allegation the donee obtained possession of the land under the decree of the companyrt of first instance but it was reversed by the High Court and the land was as a reversal restored by the companyrt to the defendant on 9th April 1895. It was observed by the High Court that  p. 736  The erroneous action of the Court of first instance cannot, we think, prejudice the defendant, or put him in a worse position that he would have occupied, had the erroneous decree number been made. This decision too, in our opinion, does number help the appellants. The possession of the defendants was disturbed by a wrong order of the companyrt which was ultimately put right and the companyrt numberdoubt acted on the maxim that a litigant is number to be prejudiced by any wrong order of the companyrt.

precedents.cited_proposition: Erroneous decree of court of first instance later reversed does not prejudice the adverse possessor or break continuity of possession
precedents.cited_holding: The erroneous action of the Court of first instance cannot... prejudice the defendant

anchor.surface_text: the main question in this appeal is, whether the defendants-appellants perfected their title to the property in respect of which partition was claimed by the plaintiffs by adverse, possession for the prescriptive-period of twelve years or more. anchor.surface_text: In our view possession by Government or the military autho- rities of immovable property under rule 75-A of the Defence of India Rules 1939 cannot be said to be in the character of an agent or by virtue of any implied permission from the true owner or occupier.

In our view possession by Government or the military autho- rities of immovable property under rule 75-A of the Defence of India Rules 1939 cannot be said to be in the character of an agent or by virtue of any implied permission from the true owner or occupier.

anchor.surface_text: The point for consideration before the High Court was and before us is, whether by such exclusive possession the heirs in the line of Bama Charan including the appellants acquired title by adverse possession to the eastern portion i.e. Bama charan Babus Bati.

The point for consideration before the High Court was and before us is, whether by such exclusive possession the heirs in the line of Bama Charan including the appellants acquired title by adverse possession to the eastern portion i.e. Bama charan Babus Bati.

In the courts below the defendants-appellants contended that the eastern two- storeyed building was neither intended to be nor was conveyed under Ex.6 series kobalas and Ex. 9 a , the sale certificate. Both the trial court and the first appellate court held that the kobalas and sale certificate were sufficiently comprehensive so as to include all or any structures

In the courts below the defendants-appellants contended that the eastern two- storeyed building was neither intended to be nor was conveyed under Ex.6 series kobalas and Ex. 9 a , the sale certificate. Both the trial court and the first appellate court held that the kobalas and sale certificate were sufficiently comprehensive so as to include all or any structures

anchor.surface_text: The last, point put forward was that the plaintiffs had not asked for possession in their plaint. This can be rejected summarily. The prayers in the plaint not only include one, for preliminary decree for partition but for the appointment of a commissioner for effecting partition of the property by separating the shares of the plaintiffs from those of the defendants in the suit property.

The last, point put forward was that the plaintiffs had not asked for possession in their plaint. This can be rejected summarily. The prayers in the plaint not only include one, for preliminary decree for partition but for the appointment of a commissioner for effecting partition of the property by separating the shares of the plaintiffs from those of the defendants in the suit property.

The High Court agreeing with the finding of the first appellate court found that there was no evidence on record to show that Bama Charan had put up the said building with his own money or that he was the exclusive owner of the said two storeyed building- or that the other co-sharers gave up their ownership of the subjacent soil and rejected the exclusive title sought to be set up with regard thereto.
